title: prevail coronavirus isolate astronauts
story: They are the astronauts and cosmonauts who have looked down on the Earth from space and the surface of the moon.They all talk about that awe-inspiring sight, and especially the realisation there are no visible borders from space and that we are all in this together.This week I spoke to US astronaut Scott Kelly, who spent  days on the International Space Station.The view from his tiny window was a stunning vision of our little planet suspended in the great blackness. The -year-old commander knows all too well what le is like on lockdown.He spent a year and a half living in a tiny tin can in close proximity to his crew.And he has some good tips for not going stir crazy.Obviously the space station astronauts had a lot of work and experiments to do, but that did not take up all of their time. And like the rest of us, they needed to keep busy.Scott has lots of common-sense advice for coping with being cooped up.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.First of all, we need to have a routine. We have to make sure we get up at the same time every morning and that we get washed and dressed and make our beds. We also need a regular bedtime.Scott says you have to get outside at least once a day — we can do that on earth — while also folowing the rules.You need to schedule times to talk to family and friends and have proper meal times.Exercise is vital. Our very own spaceman, Tim Peake, trained and completed a marathon on a running machine when he was part of the crew on the Space Station.Not all of us are fit enough to run -odd miles, but we can use this time to improve stamina and energy levels. I’m still doing my exercise classes with instructor Maxine Jones on her YouTube channel, and I will be starting virtual yoga with my daughter Rosie, who is in Singapore.I was surprised to learn Scott took actual books, not ebooks, into space.But he said holding a real book in his hands meant he could become completely absorbed, and concentration was not interrupted by messages pinging on his iPad.One of the most interesting things he said was to keep a journal of these strange times.It is more than just jotting down what you got up to that day. You need to go deeper and describe your hopes, fears and state of mind, and also what you hope to achieve when this is all over.One of the things Scott valued most during his long stint in space was video calls with family and friends. And he says one of the silver linings of this crisis is time to reconnect with loved ones.I know exactly what he means. I have been spending hours in WhatsApp chats with Rosie, my best friend Joyce, who is in lockdown in Spain, and my mum in East Kilbride.We chat about everythingand it lts my spirits. Scott’s other sensible advice is to get your information from the experts — and he advises against relying on the internet.He is right. Social media is stuffed with misinformed people and mad conspiracy ­theories.I was shocked to realise how some teens don’t watch any news outlets or read newspapers. They get their “news” from Facebook.They also think they are invincible, which is why we saw those packed beaches and parks this time last week.This was partly because they were unaware of the need for “social distancing” but also because they think it won’t happen to them.But Scott’s most important message to all of us is about working together.“All people are inescapably connected and the more we can come together to solve our problems, the better off we will be.“I’ve seen humans work together to prevail over the toughest challenges imaginable, and I know we can prevail over this one,we all do our part and work together as a team.”Well, I would urge you all to listen to Scott.If we can put a man on the moon then we can beat this awful virus. It won’t be easy but I have faith in science.And as long as we obey the rules, and make some sacrices, we WILL overcome.NO matter what you think of him, it would be churlish not to wish Boris Johnson a speedy recovery.But my sympathies are with Carrie Symonds, who is due to give birth in three months. She’s in isolation at a time when she needs his support.My thoughts are with all expectant parents now, bringing babies into a world we barely recognise and unable to be together in the delivery room. It will be bittersweet for all of them.ONE part of the world untouched by Covid- is my spiritual homeland of Antarctica.I visited the great white wilderness three years ago and cannot wait to .Aside from astronauts, the men and women who man the science bases in Antarctica – particularly the station at the South Pole – are well used to being in isolation while living on top of one another.Which is exactly what most of us are doing right now.Living space is limited at the Pole, and there’s no escaping the other  human beings holed up at the station for the full Antarctic winter.It’s virtually pitch black for six months and you can’t really go outside apart from short bursts of vital scientic work.Most are in danger of becoming “toasty”, which is their description of going stir-crazy.Being cramped, isolated and without proper personal boundaries and “me time” can make you cranky, short-tempered and irritated by the smallest things.In order for us all to avoid toastiness during these strange times, I’d recommend a few rules, some of which were given to me by a hardy survivor of winter at the extreme south.Have a sanctuary, evenit is just in the toilet reading your newspaper and doing the crossword.If you are feeling at the end of your tether, don’t bottle it up.Talk about your feelings and listen to what others in the house with you are saying.You might very well be annoying them as much as they are driving you up the wall.It’s early days, and this is a marathon and not a sprint.Unlike those at the Pole, at least we can still go outside and enjoy the sunshine and the heat as well as the light.I’VE got a Star Trek version of Monopoly and I’m wonderingit is too soon to bring it out from the back of the cupboard.I’ve never actually got to the end of a game of Monopoly and I reckon this might just be the only time that will ever happen.I’m also going to start watching Game Of Thrones for the first time, which should keep me going for a couple of weeks. Any other suggestions for box sets gratefully received.I’M sure all dog owners would agree that our fantastic, loyal, loveable pets are keeping us sane right now. I don’t know what I would doI couldn’t take Angus for a walk once a day.It’s not just a chance to get out in the fresh air and do some exercise, which is good for our physical and mental health, but it’s having something that takes your mind off the current state of the world.When I’m playing with Angus I can almost forget those feelings of anxiety that creep up on all of us and simply enjoy his energy and enthusiasm.He needs to be fed and watered and taken care of, and that gives me a much-needed sense of purpose.It’s a proven fact that just having a dog in the house to cuddle boosts your well-being and cuts stress levels.I don’t know what I would do without him.IT has never been more vital for all of us to receive clear-headed analysis and news we can trust.That’s why it’s so important you continue to buy your Sun every day.There’s a free delivery offer for those unable to get to the shops and of course there’s our splendid online version.We need to be well informed about the latest, fast-moving events and have all the facts to best protect ourselves and our families.Thank you for your loyalty and, as always, for your comments and feedback. story: THIS is the heartwarming moment a hero paramedic was applauded by her entire street as she made her way to work battling coronavirus.Tayla Porter could be seen fighting back tears as locals in Basingstoke, Hants, joined together in a show of support for the frontline worker.The -year-old was also greeted by a box of Cadburys Miniature Heroes and homemade cake on top of her car as she made her way to Basingstoke and North Hampshire hospital on Thursday.Mum Ali, , who proudly watched the round of applause with Taylas dad Phil, , and sister Tash, , said she was overcome by the response.She said: It was overwhelming for all of us.Tayla just couldnt believe it. She couldnt believe that people would even notice what shes doing. She just loves her job.I had no idea the whole street would come out. I just thought it might be our next door neighbours and the house opposite.What I didnt realise was that every single house had at least one person come out to clap her.It carried on all the way up our street and you could hear them clapping all the way up the next street too.It was so emotional, I could barely speak. title: coronavirus what chinese wet market
story: COVID-, a deadly new coronavirus which spread dramatically from its initial epicentre - the city of Wuhan - put a spotlight on China’s poorly regulated wild animal trade.While scientists are still researching the exact origin of the virus, its no secret that infectious disease specialists have for decades been raising the alarm about the accelerated pace of outbreaks, including SARS, Dengue, Ebola and Zika. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesWet markets are a series of stalls that sell fresh vegetables and fruits, live fish, chickens and other meats.They are named after the melting of ice used to preserve goods and the washing of floors to clean blood and entrails.Reuters says they have come under closer scrutiny after the coronavirus pandemic was initially linked to a seafood market in Wuhan, China.The deadly bug, called Covid-, put a spotlight on the regime’s poorly regulated wild animal trade - driven by relentless demand for exotic delicacies and ingredients for traditional medicine.China’s markets, where wild and often poached animals are packed together, have been described as a breeding ground for disease and an incubator for a multitude of viruses to evolve and jump the species barrier to humans, the news agency adds.After hundreds of people were quickly infected by the new virus, authorities said it appeared to have emerged from illegally traded wildle in a seafood market in the central Chinese city.Back in January, Gao Fu, director of China Center for Disease Control and Prevention, told a briefing: “The origin of the new coronavirus is the wildle sold illegally in a Wuhan seafood market.” That market was shut down, and authorities said they would ban illegal wildle trade and tighten supervision of wet markets.Conservationists and health experts have long denounced the trade in wildle for its impact on bioersity and the potential for spreading disease in markets.“The animal welfare part of this is obvious.But much more hidden is this stashing and mixing of all these species together in a very small area, with secretions and urine mixed up together,” warned Christian Walzer, executive director of the New York-based Wildle Conservation Society.However, Pavida Pananond, associate professor of international business at Thammasat University in Bangkok, pointed out last month: “Wet markets are part of the local culture in Asia, as people believe that meat and produce sold there is fresher and cheaper than in modern retail outlets.The - outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome , which started in China and killed about  people, was believed to have emerged from wet markets.These traditional markets are a leline for millions of small farmers, vendors and small businesses, said Pavida.She added: “It will be dficult to completely replace them as they serve consumers at the lower end of purchasing power, not to mention their cultural preference.And several months on, scientists studying the origins of the bug are still not  per cent certain as to where - and how - exactly the disease began.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: clocks change 2020 time
story: And tonight is that time of year - when the clocks go forward to kick off daylight saving time. Heres everything you need to know about the time change.On March , , the clocks will go forward one hour at am.When the clocks turn forward an hour we enter British Summer Time or BST.This means theres more daylight in the evenings, and less in the mornings.Its also sometimes known as daylight savings time.The clocks always go forward one hour on the last Sunday in March.The UK observes the clock changing twice a year, when it goes back to GMT in October.Yes -you have an iPhone then it will have automatically changedyou have your date and time options set to set automatically.For all other smartphones, network operators should change the time accordinglyyou have automatic updates set to your phone.Howeveryoure still using a regular keypad brick-style mobile you might need to change your date and time manually.Sadly, the clocks going forward means you lose an hour of sleepThe clocks go forward to make better use of daylight.When changed to BST, we move an hour of daylight from the mornings to the evenings.In the winter the clocks go back to signal the approach of winter and fewer daylight hours by ensuring there’s more daylight in the mornings and less in the evenings.To help you remember which is which, think “spring forward, fall back”.British Summer Time came into existence with the Summer Time Act that was passed by Parliament in .Germany was the first country to adopt the plan on April , , and on May , Britain followed suit, during the height of the First World War.The campaign which led to the creation of BST and Daylight Savings Timewas started by William Willett in  in a bid to stop people wasting valuable hours of light in the summer months.By setting the clocks back in winter, Brits get an earlier sunrise and earlier sunset.In summer the sun rises and sets one hour later than it would without daylight saving.In a pamphlet called The Waste of Daylight, Willett suggested clocks should be advanced by  minutes over four stages in April, and reversed the same way in September.Supporters at the time of the proposal argued the scheme would save energy by reducing domestic coal consumption.They also said it would increase supplies available for the huge manufacturing cost of the war effort.It has been in place ever since – despite criticism from some groups.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chris mclaughlin decades austerity means
story: NewsopinionChris McLaughlin: Decades of austerity means UK ill-equipped to restore economyLet’s hope the brave new world that eventually emerges from the ­corona crisis is based on more than  Big Brother-style slogans, writes Chris McLaughlinShareCommentsByChris McLaughlin:,  MAR NewsopinionBoris Johnson’s reaction has shown the old Tory instinct of leaving vulnerable behind remains a first principle" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIt couldn’t go on. The sight of groups of MPs gathering in groups to pass laws stopping the rest of us from gathering in groups was not a good look. It appeared literally like one law for the lawmakers and another for the locked-down rest of us. So Parliament upped sticks till after Easter. The Speaker had already ­announced a ban on alcohol in the Commons so it was questionable how long MPs would be able to sustain themselves anyway. The forward agenda was thin. Whether or not the scheduled Bill on toilet rate reliefwas “essential” was questionable in the current climate. But before packing their bags, MPs first had to provide legislative authority to the most draconian range of powers ever granted to the state in peacetime. Or indeed wartime. Hitler and the Luftwaffe never closed the bars or theatres and never imprisoned the population in the way that coronavirus has succeeded in doing. Forced quarantining, cancelled ­elections, allowing a single doctor – rather than two – to section people and reducing Parliamentary scrutiny of the state, including the security services. It’s a menu to whet the appetite of any would-be authoritarian tyrant. And it’s one that worries MPs. What , they fear, some of these emergency changes to the way we live were to slip into normality in the longer term  The Government was forced to accept that the powers enshrined in the Coronavirus Act – rushed through the Commons and Lords in just two days – should be reviewed every six months. How that works remains to be seen. Suspicions were raised as to whether the -page Bill – yes, parts of it have been up Whitehall’s sleeve for a while – was necessary at all. The Speaker’s own legal counsel, Daniel Greenberg, says all the ­provisions are covered by existing law. He should know – he wrote them.  The Government says the existing ones are “the wrong sort of law”. All sides in Westminster agree, the country is going through change and it must emerge stronger and better. The challenges are profound. Hot on the heels of the virus bill came another, supported by all parties, the Future Generations Bill. It calls for new procedures to take longer-term ­thinking into mainstream policy ­making, presenting Parliament with “an ­opportunity to act today for tomorrow, and level up opportunity between­ ­current and future generations”.

story: NewsopinionSaira Khan: Weirdly and selfishly self-isolation has done me the world of goodFor the first time in my le, I’ve started to answer that big question: “What is it all about ". And I think I know the answerShareBySaira Khan:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsopinionSaira Khan with her husband Steve " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHow are you feeling  That’s the first thing I get asked when I speak to ­family and friends on the phone. And I’m fine, which is the truth. I am doing okay. Because, weirdly and ­selfishly, one week’s ­self-isolation has done me the world of good. Le as I knew it stopped overnight and I’m just left with me, my two children and my husband. It sounds like a nightmare – and I know it is for a lot of people, and many are going to struggle in the coming months. But for a workaholic like me, it’s been a revelation. For the first time in my le, I’ve started to answer that big question: “What is it all about ” And I know one thing – it’s not about fame, money or a big car. It’s about humanity, family, community, ­compassion and change. I woke up one morning feeling really unsettled. I went for a run. The park, normally packed with kids, was empty. It was such a powerful vista. I could appreciate the fresh air, the grass, the birds, the flowers and be grateful for my health. Le before self-isolation for me involved passing my husband in the house, like ships in the night.  With my children, it was getting them up, rushing them from place to place until bedtime, not really listening or being present because I had a million and one other things on my mind. We were part of the rat race – work hard, make more so we could spend more. Because that is classed as success – the house, car, holidays, clothes, brands. It is how you’re judged.

The beauty and healthcare retailer has opened facilities at the theme park, as well as at its head office in Nottingham. The move is in a bid to support the Governmentaposs bid to test doctors and nurses who have been self-isolating and are unsure whether they have the virus.  The pioneering method of testing has only been used in a few locations across the country. Tests are currently being conducted by volunteers from Boots staff. It will offer free testing for NHS workers who are isolating themselves, unsurethey have coronavirus or not. Those eligible for the tests will be invited by their employer who will inform them of the process.  It comes as more than  people have now tested positive  for the virus in Nottinghamshire. Cases in Surrey almost doubled overnight on Thursday, spiking up to . By Friday, the figure had risen by another  people.  During a Government press conference on March , Michael Gove - who stood in for Boris Johnson after he tested positive for coronavirus - revealed increased testing capacity and said tests were being trialled immediately. Seb James, managing director for  Boots UK, said the company felt - as it has done for the past  years - it had a duty to step forward and be part of the solution to the ongoing crisis. He said: I am extremely proud that Boots is supporting COVID- testing for NHS workers. Boots has been at the heart of UK healthcare for  years and has always come forward to support the community in times of need. We will work with the NHS to recruit trained professionals – both Boots colleagues and from the wider community. I am sure there will be many trained healthcare clinicians and students, who will step forward to support our dedicated NHS colleagues. Locations are being defined but will be spread across the UK they will not however be in Boots stores, allowing our colleagues to focus on supporting our customers and patients.  The Government has before been criticised for its lack of testing options, particularly for NHS workers who are vital in the efforts to support those who are vulnerable and in critical need of care.

Speaking from the ship, which is stranded off the Pacic coast of Panama, -year-old Paul, from Huddersfield, said: “We feel such ­despair because we feel the Government wants to leave us adrt to die. “We haven’t had any word or a concerted effort from our Government. “The most frightening thing is we don’t know how anyone can manage the logistics of getting us home when we can’t even get into a port that will accept us.”  Cruise company Holland America is in a race to get healthy holidaymakers off the ship before the virus spreads further. Passengers are being tested for the bug and those in the clear are being transferred to sister ship, The Rotterdam, alongside it. Tonight the Wilsons’ daughter, Sally Dunkley, , said: “We are terried we will never see them again. Mum is so frightened she told us that the house now belongs to my brother and I, and Dad is checking all his le insurance is in order. “We are beyond worried. We’ve not had a word from the British Government about how they will deal with this. “The Rotterdam sent small boats with testing kits. Those who test positive will be left on the Zaandam which will essentially become a hospital ship.” The Wilsons’ ­journey went as planned until passengers started falling ill following a stop at Punta Arenas, Chile, on March . The ship tried to turn back to dock for passenger testing but was refused entry. There are fears the boat could become another Diamond Princess, which suffered  deaths after  passengers got Covid-. Guy Jones, son of fellow passengers Celia and Nick Jones, of Bristol, last night appealed for the UK Foreign Office to get involved. Nick, , a retired head teacher, and Celia, , went ahead with their holiday after Government guidelines said it was safe to travel to South America. Guy, , a theatre stage manager, said: “They seem to be quite well at the moment but our ­biggest worry is how they will get home. “When they were first put into lockdown on Monday, the announcement over the tannoy said about  people had fallen ill and it was a precautionary measure. But on Friday they were told four people had died.”  Elsewhere, British travellers stranded across the world have pleaded for chartered flights to be sent out after aircraft this week rescued , citizens stuck in Peru. Esther Hulme and Lewis Kellett, stranded in India, begged for help from the Foreign Office and claimed police “intimidate and beat” foreigners with sticks. India’s borders have been closed for  days to halt the spread of Covid- through its . billion population. Esther and Lewis, from Leeds, said they were kicked out of two hotels by staff and are now stuck in a hostel in Goa with  others, living off rice and crisps. Civil servant Esther, , said: “Today, queuing for food, police pulled out big sticks as an intimidation technique. I’ve heard of middle-aged British women left bruised from being hit. “The embassy advised us to follow local ­procedure but they don’t realise the reality.” Retired physicist John Siddle, , is among , Britons thought to be stranded in Bali. The grandad-of-three, from Southport, Merseyside, was quoted £, for a flight home via Australia to the UK.

These are just a few of the selfless hundreds of thousands who have signed up as NHS volunteers. They are ordinary people with their own worries but they are desperate to play their part in a world-wide crisis brought so close to home. From next week they will help deliver vital supplies such as food and essential medicine to the vulnerable, drive them home from hospital and make regular phone calls to those struggling in self-isolation. Here they tell compelling stories of why they have joined the fight. Iaposm honouring my murdered daughter  Andy McHugh is driven to help due to the pain of losing his daughter. Lucy, , was stabbed  times by her mum’s lodger after she threatened to expose him as an abuser. Since her death, Andy has found solace in community work and, when the plea was made for NHS volunteers, he applied immediately. He said: “I’m doing this in honour of Lucy. “She was a caring girl, she wanted to help and was always there to help her two siblings. She’d have been so happy to see how everyone is pulling together to fight this.” The teenager was killed by paedophile Stephen Nicholson, , who had been a lodger with her mum and stepdad at their Southampton home. He lured her to woodland before stabbing her in July  after she threatened to reveal he had been abusing her for a year.  Nicholson was jailed for a minimum of  years last July. Andy, , gave up his vaping business and started work as a community liaison officer after seeing the outpouring of grief for Lucy. He said: “I thought about how my mum used to sit on the doorstep with the neighbours and how things might have been dferent for Lucywe still had that sense of community and people knew what was going on in their street. “You do have to come to terms with your grief and try and move on. “Working in community has given me a bigger picture on le and when this virus has been beaten, I hope we will remember the way people came together. “Losing Lucy was the worst but sometimes you have to focus on the task in hand, and it’s all those vulnerable people in need.” Inspired by grandad who fought in World War   Emma Maslin was inspired to sign up by the example of her grandfather who fought on the beaches of Normandy in the Second World War. Her -year-old grandad Roy Chapillon is one of Britain’s . million vulnerable people self-isolating at home. Emma, , a money coach from Milton Keynes, said: “He fought in Germany and France so it seems minimal that we are being asked to stay at home bored and, even then, some people are still going out. “He’s been reading all about Covid- but I wonder how much people of his age are really worrying about it after all they’ve been through. “My mum sees him every day and stands far from his doorstep to check he’s OK but he seems to be doing reasonably well.” Emma has volunteered to talk to those who are stuck at home, saying: “It’s important we recognise the emotional toll this will have. “I’m in a fortunate position that I work from home and can phone people around my two girls who are six and eight. I’ve told them what volunteering is and why it’s important.” Mum-of-two Jo Jordan had just opened a new hair salon when the virus struck, forcing her to close. She is a single mum who lives in rented property. But rather than sit at home worrying, she has signed up as a volunteer to deliver essential medicine and food. Jo, who lives in Brough, East Yorks, said: “I know I’m not in a great position because I only opened my salon in February. “But I also know there are people a lot worse off. “I realise that somewhere down the line I will get some help, so I want to give something back. I can sit wallowing in self-pity or I can take action and think ‘Where can I help here ’.” The -year-old says she hopes the world will be a kinder place once the crisis is over. And she wants to set an example to daughters Isabelle, , and twelve-year-old Evie. “The girls have already noticed how things are changing,” she said. “We’ve been going out for a walk every day and suddenly people are taking time to say hello to each other. “I just hope it will last.” Helping lonely people during the lockdown  Andrew Ward and we Kate worry about how the lonely will cope. They were thinking about volunteering when the call went out for people to support the NHS. As a mental first-aider at his job in financial services, Andrew is qualied to help those struggling at home. Andrew, , of Beckenham, South London, said: “Listening to people is critical. I can recognise someone in distress and signpost them to the right places for help.” Kate added: “We are both well. Making calls to people who could benefit is something that comes naturally to both of us.” Iaposm scared for my intensive care nurse sister

title: coronavirus hero supermarket workers keeping
story: NewsCoronavirus: Hero supermarket workers keeping the UK running through lockdownFriends and family pay tribute to the people stacking the shelves so the rest of the nation can get the food they needShareCommentsByDan Kemp:,  MAR NewsThe employees of ious grocery stores are facing incredible pressure " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Day after day, hero supermarket workers are going to work to make sure the nation has enough food as the coronavirus pandemic continues to ramp up in the UK.The employees of ious grocery stores are facing incredible pressure from panic buying and stockpiling customers, while also trying to keep their stores as clean and safe as possible to prevent the spread of the killer disease. Each morning, pictures emerge on social media showing queues of people lining up two metres apart outside supermarkets as they scramble to get their hands on essential items.But despite all this, supermarket staff have been going above and beyond in the face of adversity, reports Hull Live.Family, friends and customers have paid tribute to those working in food stores in Hull and East Riding to ensure everyone can still access their share of food. Donna Hammond has praised her mum and dad, Annette and Philip Dockerty, who have been waking up at am to keep the shelves stocked at Sainsbury’s. She said: “My mum and dad getting up at am every morning to start at am at Sainsbury’s in Hessle. “A massive shout out to them both for keeping that bread coming. We all love you and stay safe.” Meanwhile, Kay Brindle showed her support to her friend who “brightens customers’ day” at the same company. She said: Debs Collinson, my pal who always has a smile on her face and makes and brightens customers’ day with her infectious laugh, who works at Sainsbury’s in Anlaby.”  Staff at Asda in Savoy Road are “exhausted and run off their feet” but that has not stopped them putting in extra hours to keep the community refuelled. Danielle Hunt said: “ASDA Savoy Road in Hull. “We are working extra hours days. We are exhausted and run off our feet but still remain with a friendly and customer focused team as always. I for one am so proud of this team.” Claire Grantham has appealed for people to not go shopping “for the sake of it” while celebrating her “amazing” mum. “My amazing mum Jill is working every day at Sainbury’s in Hessle. Only go out for the essentials, don’t go shopping for the sake of it and keep your distance from the staff when you are in store. “Remember they only get paid minimum wage.” Claire Woodley’s daughter Cha has health problems but is going far beyond what is expected both at work and to help her family. She is working hard at BM in Willerby and also checking on neighbours and grandparents to make sure they have enough. Sharing a picture of her daughter, Claire said: “This is my daughter Cha Oaten who is an amputee and has health problems.  She is working long hours in BM Willerby, messaging her grandma and neighbours to seethey need anything bringing home and making sure we have everything we need so we donapost have to go to the shops.” Bakery staff at Sainsbury’s in Hedon have also been singled out for praise.

story: NewsCoronavirus lockdown flouted by group of eight enjoying picnic of kebabs and shishaA group of disobedient picnickers had to be dispersed by Derbyshire Constabulary after gathering at Snake Pass in the Peak District to eat kebabs and smoke shisha amid the coronavirus lockdownShareCommentsByJeremy Culley:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsFriends flout social distancing advice with a picnic and smoking shisha pipes at Snake Pass " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Eight friends who were caught enjoying a picnic in the sun are among dozens of Brits who have been pictured flouting coronavirus lockdown rules.The disobedient group, who had been eating kebabs and smoking shisha, were found perched on a hill in the Peak District on Thursday. They were dispersed by police after travelling to Snake Pass in Derbyshire from Manchester and Sheffield, despite strict warnings to stay at home to halt the spread of Covid-.It came just four days after Prime Minister Boris Johnson urged Brits not to venture outside unless shopping for food, attending a medical appointment or helping someone vulnerable, going to essential work or for exercise once a day.Posting pictures of the gathering, Derbyshire Constabulary tweeted: “Snake Pass. Large groups gathering enjoying picnics, kebabs and shisha. “Visitors from Manchester, Sheffield and Ipswich. Dispersed with no resistance but seriously this is not social distancing and staying home.” Twitter users were equally unimpressed, with one writing: “Should have blockaded the road both ways and left them stranded.”Another called them “imbeciles”, commenting: “They need fining to pay for police time.”Meanwhile, another user said: “Take the names and national insurance numbers . Refuse them any help within theNHS .“We have rules and need to abide by them.”  However they weren’t the only ones caught ignoring pleas from the government and NHS workers to stay at home. Sunbathers were pictured soaking up rays in a number of spots across the UK yesterday, including Southsea, Bournemouth and Somerset. Derbyshire Police has been accused of “nanny policing” after using drone cameras to film people walking in the Peak District.

title: coronavirus lockdown rules stop teenagers
story: NewsCoronavirus lockdown rules stop teenagers mourning dead friend at her funeralHollys family asked her friends to wear pink for her, in lieu of being able to attend the funeralShareCommentsByLuke TraynorAlice Peacock:,  MAR NewsHollys mum, Hayley Smallman, holding a heart shaped cushion of her girl " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The farewell of a well-loved teenager was downscaled because of stringent social distancing rules due to the country being in the midst of a coronavirus lockdown.Holly Smallmanaposs pink coffin arrived at her funeral yesterday to a crowd of just , in accordance with measures implemented to prevent the spread of COVID-.While attendance at the funeral itself was small, well wishers lined the streets of Liverpool to say their goodbyes, the Liverpool Echo reported. Many of those who knew Holly wore pink for the severely-ill -year-old, in accordance with her mum Hayleyaposs wishes.  But it was at the familyaposs home in  Fazakerley,  and close to the usually-packed crematorium on Priory Road where the most fervent tears were shed.A horse and carriage was still permitted by undertakers, and it processed along Walton Vale and Queenaposs Drive on its way to Hollyaposs last resting place. About  yards from the crematorium, mum Hayley, , climbed out of the funeral car, together with her husband Gary, and two other children, Ruby, , and Josh, . They looked on with appreciation at people who had decided to line the street, keeping their social distance of two-metres apart, many who were also wearing pink.  Hayley clutched a heart-shaped cushion, with Hollyaposs picture on it, and smiled and mouthed aposThank youapos to onlookers who burst into applause for the young BBC Hospital TV star. The horse-drawn carriage was decorated with pink balloons, but perhaps most touchingly of all, was the teenaposs small coffin, in the same symbolic colour. An onlooker, who watched the Smallman family from a distance, told the ECHO: It was upsetting to see, but at the same time, so much love on show. Hayley and her family put brave faces on throughout, thanking everyone who came to see them. But at the same time, you could see she was clearly in torment. Rising early on the day of the funeral, Hayley said: Today’s the day, Hol, that I desperately prayed would never come. You are my whole world and more.  I can’t give you the day I planned, but I promise that this world will be a little bit pinker today. Because Hol, you’re amazing just the way you are. The mum-of-three sent the ECHO a photo of her daughteraposs funeralaposs pink coffin, inscribed with the words, To be continued, adding how the family had been decorating her forever bedroom on Thursday evening. Hayley simply added: I think we need to finish the story, donapost we   The parentaposs message throughout the past week, after getting the devastating news many of Hollyaposs family and friends could not attend because of Covid- social distancing rules, was to wear pink for her cherished daughter.Coleen Rooney dressed herself in a pink T-shirt, and told her .m followers on Twitter : Wearing pink today for Holly Smallman.A special little angel who went to Claire House with our Rosie. Our thoughts and prayers are with the Smallman family on this sad day.  Members from Merchant Tayloraposs School in Crosby observed the colourful request, and Claire House, the Merseyside childrenaposs hospice, who knew Holly well, saying: Today, everyone here is thinking of the Smallman family. Strict rules, introduced earlier this week because of Covid-, meant the family could not even touch Hollyaposs coffin before it left for cremation. Unless they lived in the same household, relatives were advised not to hug, and seats at the Anfield place of rest were kept far apart during the short service.

Tayla Porter was overwhelmed with emotion by the impromptu reception as she left for her sht at Basingstoke and North Hampshire Hospital. The -year-old emergency care assistant was left with her head in her hand unable to hold back tears as her mum Ali, , dad Phil,  and sister Tash, , watched on. Ali had mentioned on a local forum that her daughter would miss the national clap for carers at pm as she would be in work by pm.  But she thought nothing of it until the family stepped outside and were greeted by an entire street clapping. Ali said: “We barely know anyone on our street. It must have been people texting people or word of mouth, because not everyone is on there.”   Ali shared a video of the emotional encounter on Facebook which has now been shared more than , times and thousands of likes.She wrote: “I just love where we live, everyone in our street united to wave Tayla off on her paramedic sht tonight just the boost she needed. “The heroes chocolates and homemade cake were a lovely touch.” Tayla - who hopes to become a lead paramedic - even had to leave her younger sister Tash to celebrate her st birthday to head out on sht.  Ali said: Thereaposs been some nights where Taylaaposs come back and weaposve had to sit down and sheaposs had a bit of a cry from being exhausted. Sheaposs seeing things that are quite scary. title: coronavirus worlds oldest man celebrates
story: NewsCoronavirus forces world’s oldest man to celebrate th birthday aloneBob Weighton lived through the Spanish flu pandemic which decimated the worlds population when he was ten - and is about to celebrate his th birthday in coronavirus lockdownShareCommentsByKara ONeillBen Mitchell:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsBob is about to turn  but he doesnt want another birthday telegram from the Queen " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The world’s oldest man is being forced to celebrate his birthday alone in self-isolation thanks to the coronavirus outbreak.Bob Weighton, who turns  tomorrow, said the planned festivities are now a “dead loss” after everything had to be cancelled since gatherings of two or more people are banned for the foreseeable future. Bob took the title of oldest man in the world last month after the death of the previous holder, Chitetsu Watanabe of Japan. Last year, the former teacher and engineer celebrated with his many friends at his retirement flat but this year the supercentenarian - someone aged  and older - is under lockdown like the rest of the country. He said: Everything is cancelled, no visitors, no celebration. Itaposs a dead loss as far as celebration is concerned. Mr Weighton lived through the Spanish flu pandemic which swept around the globe in , when he was  years old, killing between  and  million people.He said: I only read about it in history books when I got older. Actually I wasnapost aware there was a Spanish flu around because none of my brothers and sisters or people I knew were affected. I am sure they were, but a childaposs world is not an adultaposs world, a child doesnapost read the newspapers and there was no radio in those days so you didnapost get news in the sense you get it thrown at you in all directions nowadays. Mr Weighton said that now the world is in a bit of a mess with coronavirus and it worries him because nobody knows what is going to happen.  He added that, unlike the two World Wars he lived through, the challenge of Covid- is the unknown elements of battling the virus. He said: In the Second World War you knew what you had to do, you might fail but the objectives were clear as Churchill rallied the country behind him, aposWe will fight on the beachesapos, etc etc. We knew exactly what we had to do. That was an objective that you could possibly reach, but nobody knows how we are going to defeat the virus.  He said the impact on him of self-isolation was that he had become more dependent on the Brendon care home where he lives, particularly for meals and from the assistant who helps him clean and lt heavier objects. He said: It means that I have to be more self-sufficient, do my own cooking, cleaning, read the books that I havenapost read. “I am less capable of doing things for myself than I was  years ago - I canapost lt the weights, I canapost move as fast, I canapost even dress myself properly. I depend very much on other people these days.  Mr Weighton said he had no secret to his longevity, adding: I never intended to be this old. When you are young, you donapost think about what is going to happen when youaposre old, youaposre self-engaged, all you think about is the here and now. But he did say that his wide general interests from reading to constructing model windmills keep him active and young. Those are things you do either naturally or donapost do. People who complain are those who donapost explore things that they might do themselves, he said. Mr Weighton added that he has turned down the traditional birthday greeting from the Queen. I wonapost be getting one because I donapost want one, he said.

title: dads life saved after parent
story: NewsDads le is saved after parent on the school run offers him his kidneyEXCLUSIVE Mark Wilson feared time was running out but then met Andy McCall while they were waiting to pick up their daughtersShareCommentsByHarriet Whitehead:,  MAR NewsAndy and Mark after the operation " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA chat at the school gates with a fellow dad saved Mark Wilson’s le. Mark, , was seriously ill with kidney disease but feared time was running out as he waited for a donor. He opened up to Andy McCall, , as they waited for their daughters. In an act of incredible selflessness, Andy offered to seehe was a match. Blood and tissue tests confirmed he was and the transplant went ahead on Valentine’s Day this year. Mark said: “When Andy offered, I couldn’t believe it. He was pretty much a complete stranger. “When my family heard he was a match, we burst into tears. Even the kidney co-ordinator was crying. “It felt like our paths meant to cross. He knows I’ll never be able to repay him. He has saved my le.”  Andy said: “Helping Mark was a no-brainer. “I had the chance to shape someone ’s le. There’s no better feeling.” Now the two fitness fans, who both have two young children, are the best of friends. A year ago Mark’s world came crashing down as he and we Victoria, , a marketing executive, from Gourock, near Glasgow, were planning a holiday with children, Emilie, five, and one-year-old Lucas.A routine check through his work at an Audi bodyshop found his blood pressure was up almost double.Mark, who works out three times a week, looked so healthy that medics initially thought there was something wrong with their kit. “They said, ‘There must be something wrong with the readings because you shouldn’t be able to stand’,” he recalled.  But tests at Glasgow’s Queen Elizabeth Hospital showed he had  per cent kidney . He was diagnosed with stage five kidney disease and told he needed a transplant. By August, his kidneyhad declined to just seven per cent and he was told he would need to begin peritoneal dialysis, which uses the lining of the abdomen to filter the blood. He had a tube fitted in his stomach so he could carry out the treatment himself four times a day. Mark recalled: “Dialysis meant I couldn’t work anymore, and I actually started to feel ill for the first time. “I had no energy and could no longer play with the children for long, or go to the gym.”  We Victoria nicknamed him “the healthiest looking sick guy”. She explained: “When he was diagnosed, people kept saying to him ‘you don’t look sick’ or ‘for someone so ill you look great’ so I said one day he was the healthiest looking sick guy I’d ever seen and then the name stuck.” One day Mark got chatting to Andy, a college apprentice co-ordinator from Greenock, at the school gates as they collected their daughters from nursery. Struck by the similarities between the young families, Andy thought about what it would be likehis le was turned upside down. Meanwhile, Mark’s mum and we offered a kidney but they were not perfect matches. With Mark in desperate need of a donor, Victoria decided to run a km race to raise money for Kidney Research UK.She uploaded a post explaining her husband’s situation to Facebook, which was spotted by Andy.Moved by what he read, Andy – father of Lily, five, and Lewis, two, with his radiographer we Laura – offered to help. “It just felt like it could so easily be me,” he said. “The thought that my le could be taken away from me in an instant really hit home. “I said to Laura, ‘Our families are so similar, we are the same age, with kids the same age, and Mark and I are both into our fitness’.”The four-hour transplant operation took place with both dads side by side inhospital beds.Andy said: “Before we went in, we had our picture taken and wished one another other good luck.” Andy was able to be by Mark’s bedside as he came round from surgery. “I felt proud that I’d been given the opportunity to help change his le and his family’s le. It was an emotional moment,” said Andy. “I told him he was looking really good and we gave each other a high five.” Within  hours of the transplant, Mark’s kidneywent from six to . per cent. Andy stayed in hospital for three days, during which time he was a frequent visitor to Mark’s room. Mark was discharged after a week and both families got together the following night to toast his health with champagne. After taking a couple of months off work to recover, keen runner Andy is back to full health and was even able to run again just over a week after the operation. Mark is feeling “better than ever”. Victoria said: “After the operation, Mark immediately looked better, his blue eyes had started shining again and after a few days he was back on his feet, gradually building up strength and taking gentle exercise.” Having forged a lelong friendship, the men have been out for dinner and drinks, as well as taking their children to soft play together. Mark said: “We’re having to isolate for now because of Covid- but we’ve been keeping each other entertained over WhatsApp. “We’re in touch most days. And now I’ve got a runner’s kidney, maybe I’ll join him for a jog. “As well as getting a new kidney, I’ve got a new friendship. It’s hard to put into words how much it means.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email TV legend Sir David Attenborough today warns the world not to let coronavirus deflect it from another global battle – with climate change.The champion of the natural world is washing his hands and observing social distance guidelines like the rest of us. But Sir David – whose film A Le On Our Planet has been put back to November because of the pandemic – says the virus is no real surprise. He tells the Sunday Mirror: “There’s always been plagues. There are diseases.“That is part of the natural world and tightly packed as we are and travel as we do, it is hardly surprisingit spreads. Get all the latest coronavirus updates in our LIVE blog“We have a short term problem with coronavirus so we quarantine and do this or that. “The consequence is, nobody takes any action on the climate at allwe are not careful.“We hope the film can be part of the public debate and show that when governments are bothered, theytake action. “The environmental crisis is coming to a very critical point where politicians need convincing by the electorate that the electorate are serious.” Sir David’s movie was due for release next month. It charts his astonishing -year career and highlights just how the natural world is being eroded. He also hopes it will be shown in schools as a warning to the next generation.  The veteran campaigner feels guilty about his own carbon footprint – and even frets about putting the heating on. But he accepts there are environmental pitfalls to modern le. Sir David, , says: “I thought I’d put on a jersey and not turn on the electric bar to write what I had been writing and, of course, you do those things. But let’s not say, ‘Forgive me for breathing’. ■ Sir David was raised at the former university college, Leicester, where his father was the principal. ■ The renowned globetrotter doesn’t drive – he never passed his test. ■ He likes all animals except rats, saying: “I can’t think of anything more ghastly – it’s come out a bloody sewer!” ■ Sir David first applied to work at the BBC as a radio producer but didn’t get the job. it was TV’s gain. ■ He has one place to tick off on his travel wishlist – the Gobi Desert, which spans china and Mongolia. “We all have a carbon footprint, but it doesn’t mean you have to wear a hairshirt or don’t ever cross the Atlantic. “It’s perfectly proper to travel in Europe in order to live a civilised le, and producing carbon dioxide is inevitable so we couldn’t suddenly say we’ve got to stop living. “All you can do is make sure you live to certain standards and take elementary attitudes towards electricity.”

Research carried out by Oxford Universityaposs Evolutionary Ecology of Infectious Disease group suggests that Covid- may have reached the UK by mid-January at the latest. The scenario is one of the several the researchers presented as possible, and goes against previously understood death rates. In the non-peer reviewed study they suggest that the coronavirus, like many emerging infections, may have spread invisibly for a month before its effects became clear at the end of February. If the Oxford researchers are right, then as much as half of the countryaposs population may already have been infected. Many people have contactedto claim that they experienced symptoms linked to Covid- in the weeks following the New Year. Below are the eight symptoms that may suggest you have already been infected by the coronavirus. Get all the latest coronavirus updates in our LIVE blog Eye infections New research has indicated that eye infection such as conjunctivitis may be a symptom of Covid-. The College of Optometrists said: It is recognised that any upper respiratory tract infection may result in viral conjunctivitis as a secondary complication, and this is also the case with Covid-. However, it is unlikely that a person would present with viral conjunctivitis secondary to Covid- without other symptoms of fever or a continuous cough as conjunctivitis seems to be a late feature where is has occurred. A dry cough Perhaps the most recognisable of the Covid- symptoms, given how dferent it can sound compared to a typical cough. The cough is generally new for you - or dferentyou generally have a smokeraposs cough - and persistant. More often than not it will last for at least half a day. Mental fatigue    Although this has not been officially chalked up as a symptom, Covid- sufferers have reported experiencing mental fatigue. Thea Jourdan told The Daily Mail that she first thought she may have been infected when she got a tickle in her throat and a headache. The mum-of-three then began to experience brain fog. Initially I felt exhausted, asI was dragging myself through treacle and had no choice but to go to my bed. I had no meaningful cough and I wasn’t running a fever, the Hampshire woman told the publication. But I had a peculiar sensation of something settling deep within my lungs, almost like breathing in talcum powder. A high temperature    Although numbers y for dferent people, a rise in body temperature generally counts as a fever once it reaches .C . You can tell you have a feveryou feel hot to the touch on your chest or back. Itaposs dficult to catch your breath If your chest starts to feel tight or you cannot breath, you may have caught the coronavirus. Most young people or those without pre-existing health conditions are unlikely to experience this symptom. Dyspnea - the term for when someone has dficulty breathing - may be coupled with a tightness in the chest, rapid breathing and heart palpatations. Loss of sense of smell and taste    Over the weekend the British Association of Otorhinolaryngology warned that losing your sense of smell and taste may mean you have Covid-. The ear, nose and throat specialist recommended anyone with such symptoms self-isolate immediatley. It has been suggested that the phenomena may be caused by the coronavirus killing cells in the nose and throat. Evidence from other countries that the entry point for the coronavirus is often in the eyes, nose and throat areas, the Association said in a statement. We have also identied a new symptomthat may mean that people without other symptoms but with just the loss of this sense may have to self-isolate - again to reduce the spread of the virus. Tummy ache    As with a loss of appetite, enduring a tummy ache may easily be passed off as a sign of something more innocuous. However, a newly published study by the American Journal of Gastroenterology links tummy problems to Covid-. They found that .% of  people who have been infected by the coronavirus in Chinaaposs Hubei province had digestive symptoms such as diarrhoea. Physical fatigue    Another common symptom of Covid-, as well as cold, flu and many viruses in general, is feeling tired or fatigued. Being told to rest is common when you’re ill, but feeling tired and not being able to sleep due to coughs and dficulty breathing, can make things all the more dficult. Jaimuay Sae-ung, , was the first Thai national to contract coronavirus in December last year.

His daughter Louise, , said: “There were many times when we thought weaposd lose him but he just kept fighting. “My dad is an absolute warrior.” Tam, who lives in Linwood, Scotland, was previously fit and healthy and enjoyed walking his beloved German Shepherd Zak before his double heart attack in October. The former fire station janitor was told he would need a stent inserted into his heart after his cardiac arrests but while waiting for surgery he developed a chest infection and doctors were unable to operate.  On Christmas Eve he was admitted to hospital after his condition worsened before undergoing a quadruple bypass on December . But complications arose during surgery and left Tam’s brain starved of oxygen. Despite everything he pulled through and was sent home in January. But just a few weeks later he was rushed to hospital after he haemorrhaged during the night. He was sent to intensive care with severe internal bleeding. Tam then suffered multiple strokes between late January and early February and lost all his cognitive movement. “He couldn’t even hold a cup,” added his daughter Louise. But the mum-of-three said that with the help of amazing NHS staff, Tam recovered and began to show signs of his old self. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A grandmother who survived both world wars and the Spanish flu outbreak of  died hours after being diagnosed with coronavirus.Hilda Churchill died at Kenyon Lodge care home, in Little Hulton earlier today. The -year-old did not have severe symptoms and her family had hoped she would pull through to celebrate her th birthday on April , reports the Manchester Evening News. Hilda first showed signs of the virus four days ago and a test came back positive, confirming she was suffering from Covid-. Hilda is thought to be the oldest person in Greater Manchester to have contracted the virus. Her grandson Anthony Churchill says she will be greatly missed by her large extended family. “She did so much for us,” he says. “We were always with her on weekends as kids. She did so much for all the grandkids. “She was a proper grandma as well. She would always have a pinny on and she’d be baking. She just could not throw any food away. You’d never go hungry. “She was very loving. She couldn’t do enough for people.” Originally from Crewe, Hilda moved up to Salford with her husband during the depression to find work. Born in , the former seamstress, was a popular figure with her neighbours and was known for her kind nature and baking skills. “She always talks about the neighbours cadging a pinch of salt and other bits during the war,” Anthony says. “She’d still make the best homemade gravy I have ever tastedyou let her near a kitchen.  “And her scones and mince pies - people were queuing up the street to get them at Christmas. “She was very independent. She hated anyone having to do anything for her.” In the weeks before her death, Anthony had started to talk to his grandma about the virus. She was able to offer a perspective on the pandemic that few others could. He says: “My grandma likes to talk. As I was telling her about his coronavirus she started talking about the Spanish flu and she remembered how bad that was. “The whole house came down with it except her mum, who looked after everyone . “Sadly her little sister, who was only  months old, died of it. Grandma said she remembers a small box being put in a carriage. “Her dad collapsed in the street with it, but survived. “She was saying how amazing it is that something you can’t see can be so devastating.” Anthony, , says Hilda was in good health up until recently having never smoked or drunk much in her le and after staying active for decades. She only moved into the care home ten months ago and, up until then, had lived alone in her home in Walkden.  The mother-of-four, grandmother of eleven and great grandmother of  had, in recent years, also welcomed great grandchildren into the family. Anthony says: “My grandma never understood how she got so old and she’d say that. I think it was the hard work that kept her going. That and good genes.” He adds: “She remembered seeing planes in the sky for the first time and very few cars on the road. “She could have written a book of the changes she’s seen in her letime. It’s very eye opening.” Anthony, from Middleton, says the care home closed their doors just over a week ago and he last saw his grandma three days before that.

Many dogs have had their routines disrupted and some will not be able to leave the house or garden for exercise or to let of steam in the park. Indoor games can stop them from chewing up furniture and getting bored and noisy and are a great way to put a smile on your face too. It is a good idea to put toys and treat bags away after your play session, ending with a nice “finish” cue so they understand the game is over. Here, Blue Cross has compiled some indoor games to play with your dog to get through the weeks ahead. Find it Show your dog a treat then throw it across the room for them to find. You can also play this game with a ballyour dog is more toy-orientated. Hide and seek One person keeps the other dog distracted while the other hides. Then you tell the dog to find them. Fetch! Play fetch inside the home with soft toys that do not bounce – so you don’t break the telly. Ensure you do this on a carpeted floor to avoid your pet slipping when they are racing about. Tug of war A game of tug can be a great way of exercising them indoors – plus it will teach them about self-discipline when rules are put in place to make sure the fun.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn NHS worker said to be the UK’s first mum-to-be to test ­positive for coronavirus has recovered from the illness – and is enjoying a healthy pregnancy. Sophie Biddle, , revealed she is fit and well in a welcome piece of good news amid the pandemic gloom. She was in her second trimester when she was diagnosed four weeks ago. Sophie even felt her baby kick for the first time while in self-isolation. Fortunately her symptoms were mild. After two weeks in isolation, she has been given the all-clear toto her job as an NHS physiotherapist. That means she will soon be treating patients in the community who are themselves recovering from wretched Covid-. Get all the latest coronavirus updates in our LIVE blog Sophie had her -week scan last Monday and it revealed she is expecting a healthy baby boy. Speaking out to other expectant mums – like Carrie Symonds, who is self-isolating after her PM fiancé Boris Johnson got the virus – Sophie said: “I’ve had a lot of messages from pregnant women worried about the virus. “So, while everyone is dferent, I want people to know that I recovered quickly. The NHS were brilliant and I’m really proud to work with them. “I’m going to be treating patients who are recovering from Covid-. “I’m probably one of the safest people to be around now!”  Sophie, from Chelmsford in Essex, began experiencing mild symptoms of the virus in late February when her partner ed from Milan. The city has been under lockdown for weeks as badly-hit Italy struggles to contain the virus. But Sophie thinks it’s equally possible she could have picked up the illness on her crowded commute to London. She said: “I had a cough, a runny nose and a headache, and took three days off work. Then my partner developed symptoms – he was slightly feverish and chesty.  “We rang  purely because of my partner’s travel history and then things really kicked off. “We were told to drive to AE and sit outside with our hazard lights on and stay in the car, where a nurse in a hazmat suit posted nasal swabs through the car window.” Sophie and her partner were sent home to self-isolate. But medics told them to sleep in separate rooms as they were unsurethey had built up immunity – and were worried they could reinfect each other. By this point, Sophie had started to feel better. She kept herself fit by doing ballet barre-style exercises in her isolation room. On March  she got a call from Public Health England to confirm she had tested positive.  Sophie, who has been writing an isolation blog, said: “My first reaction was shock, really. “I said, ‘Are you sure ’ But as my symptoms were mild I knew I’d be okay and they’d have a plan for me.” As the UK was still trying to contain the virus at this point, health officials called Sophie repeatedly. They took names and contact numbers of everyone she had been in recent contact with, and called the hospital where she worked to find out whether anyone  had been ­experiencing symptoms. Sophie went on: “My brother had been visiting from Sweden so they tested him too. “But he didn’t have the virus. Some people were scared when they found out they’d had contact with us. “But once they learned a bit more about the virus they were more understanding. “The whole time I was off work, I had absolutely amazing support from the NHS.”

title: mark steel boris stance builders
story: NewsopinionMark Steel: Boris advice for builders must come from all the plumbing he learnt at EtonIf you believe what the scientists and doctors are saying, why would you think it’s all right for one million building workers to carry on working ShareCommentsByMark Steel:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsopinionCoronavirus outbreak builders still working South Quay Plaza " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMost of us understand it’s vital we stay indoors, unless our work keeps others alive. This is why the workplaces allowed to carry on are hospitals, supermarkets – and building sites. Because it’s essential in these harsh times that we finish building -storey glass office blocks on the edge of Leeds, so they can remain empty for nine years before being let out to an insurance company from Saudi Arabia. Some people suggest building firms are exempt because their owners have complained they can’t let their profits suffer. But that’s too cynical. The real reason must be that it’s crucial for our morale to still hear the distant thud of a JCB churning up concrete. It makes a pretty harmony with the blackbirds and gives us a reason to keep going. Given how this virus spreads, to have one million building workers still operating will almost certainly add to the fatalities. But never mind because while their families will miss Uncle Sid, they’ll know it was through his sacrice that it was possible to complete a block of riverside apartments no one can afford. And they will carry that pride forever.  The Prime Minister took care to protect builders, saying it would be possible for them to do their work safely by always staying six feet apart. This must come from Boris Johnson’s extensive experience of working on building sites. Because plastering, roofing and plumbing are the first things you learn at Eton. So these instructions should make building work fun, as labourers throw bags of cement and bricks and scaffold pipes at each other from two metres, with their colleagues ing to catch them. Carpenters will shout: “You hold that in place, Dave, and I’ll put this nail through it with my eight-foot-long hammer.”  And as long as everyone remembers not to get close when they’re handing someone a cup of tea, but put it in a bucket and deliver it by crane, they’ll all be perfectly safe. If you believe what the scientists and doctors are saying, why would you think it’s all right for one million building workers to carry on working  The Government must have information they haven’t told us. Maybe the virus can’t get through a high-vis jacket. Or tea with four or more sugars is the antidote, so builders are immune.  Also, the number travelling into work has been cut to one-third of normal, but the number of trains and tubes running has also been cut to one-third of normal. So the trains are exactly as packed as they always were. Still, it would be unfair to expect the Government to work out dficult sums like that, with everything  they have to do.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe heartbreaking ­sight of a box of abandoned ­kittens was the spark ­to a revolution in animal rights. Trainee banker Ingrid Newkirk could not leave the helpless creatures so she took them to a shelter. Her visit to the dank and squalid refuge would change her le – and triggered her crusade to improve the care and welfare of animals. And in March  Ingrid founded the campaign group Peta – People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. Its high-profile protests and by backing of glamorous stars who would bare all for the cause has turned it into one of the world’s most ­formidable animal rights’ group.  Big name actresses include Pamela Anderson, Kim Basinger, Gillian Anderson and Eva Mendes have all stripped off for Peta. Its hard-hitting campaigns aimed to show the truth behind industries such as animal-tested products and industrial meat production. Ingrid, now , said: “Politics, sex and conflict always dominates the news. Causes are always struggling to make it on to the news but everyone looks at ­celebrities. Everyone looksthe word naked is there. We seized on those two things.” Some of Peta’s most shocking moments include ex-Baywatch star Anderson’s near naked body labelled like an animal carcass in  and nude Spanish model Elen Rivas opposing bullfighting with spears in her back. Porn star Jenna Jameson ­campaigned for the use of pleather – plastic leather.  Peta’s  “Holocaust on your plate” demo compared factory ­farming to human death camps and caused outrage. Peta has grown into the world’s largest animal rights organisation with . million members and supporters.Ingrid has led from the front having stripped off and been thrown in prison cells for her protests. Softly spoken but steely in her resolve, Ingrid never planned a le of activism. As a child she loved meat and at , living in her native Surrey, even purchased a squirrel fur coat which she thought she looked “fabulous” in. But finding the kittens in Washington DC in  changed all that. She persuaded workers at the shelter to give her a job.  Peta started with like-minded ­people thinking how they could be kinder to animals. Ingrid slowly changed. She ­inspected homes and farms for the shelter and became a vegetarian after seeing a dead piglet. When she saw a dead squirrel and fox, she threw away her fur coat and fox pelt collar. She said: “My boyfriend sent me a roast chicken when I became vegetarian, knowing I wouldn’t be able to resist the smell. I had to sit him down and tell him ‘I love meat and don’t want to give it up so you have to support me to do this’. He was humbled.”  Peta attracted worldwide ­attention after its first campaign which exposed the treatment of  wild-born macaque monkeys from the Philippines being kept in the Institute for Behavioural Research in Silver Spring, Maryland, US. Peta has legions of ­supporters but Ingrid herself has been the star of many campaigns, including its call to strip off: “I’d ­rather go naked than wear fur.” She said: “When I strip off I’m always a bit knock kneed, it’s often cold just wearing ­knickers. You are like Lady Goa,not as ­attractive, ­doing something to make people think twice about animal cruelty.”  Ingrid has also hung topless from a butcher’s hook beside headless pigs in , broken into the US Vogue offices been thrown in the New York cells with rock star Chrissie Hynde after demonstrating in a Gap store in Manhattan. She said: “With the pig ­campaign, the butchers were there, the carcass cutters were there and they all came out to have a look at me. “I wanted them to look. They are the ones that cut the heads off the pig. My body is the same colour as the pigs’. The only dference was I still had my head on. They came out to mock but ended up quite quiet.”  Peta’s campaigns achieved changes in the fashion industry’s attitude to fur. Designers ­including Victoria Beckham, Prada and Chanel banned it from their runways. Ingrid, who lives in Washington DC, won’t even let death stop her campaigning. After narrowly surviving a light aircraft flight she made provisions for her corpse to be of use. She said: “My liver will go to France to protest the force feeding of ducks and geese for foie gras. I want a leg made into an umbrella stand because elephant’s legs are made into knick-knacks. I want part of my flesh to be cooked with ­onions and garlic and people to be told that it’s human flesh – what dference does it make ”

The Prince was duped in two phone calls with notorious jokers Vladimir Kuznetsov and Alexey Stolyarov, during which he indiscreetly told them he is “completely separate” from most of the Royal Family and spoke openly about his agony over “Megxit”.He also opened up to the fake Greta about the tension at the heart of the Royal Family and was also critical of US president Donald Trump. Mr Markle said: “We all think we do something right and it turns out to be wrong. “Harry recently made a huge mistake talking to those Russian pranksters. “He got tricked by those pranksters and I got tricked by doing those photos.  “We all make mistakes and I made a huge mistake. “I should forgive them and they should forgive me. “Ultimately, maybe it’s time for Archie to say hello to grandpa.”  Thomas lives alone in Rosarito, Mexico, just over the border from Calornia, which is now in Covid- lockdown. He has been suffering from a cold for the last two months, but insists it is not coronavirus.  He is now preparing to go into self-isolation in Mexico. He said: “I have a good supply of food in, I’m ready to self-isolate and stay at home. I have more than enough food and water.” Thomas is now preparing to be a witness in the legal battle over a letter Meghan wrote to him detailing her heartbreak at their rt. He originally kept silent about Meghan’s five-page note posted to his home. But six months later its existence was revealed in a US magazine, anonymously quoting fivefriends of Meghan. Thomas felt the nameless pals attacked him and misrepresented the letter, prompting him to take it to a UK newspaper.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email People with Downaposs syndrome, cerebral palsy and autism could be left to die of coronavirus under new guidelines in the United States.Measures have been suggested for doctors on who to prioritize for treatment as the country grapples with an outbreak seemingly out of control. Disability advocates say they are aposdisturbedapos by the guidelines published by the state of Alabama on rationing ventilators should the pandemic stretch their resources. New guidance published Alabama officials says that ‘persons with severe mental retardation, advanced dementia or severe traumatic brain injury may be poor candidates for ventilator support.’ It goes on to say that ‘persons with severe or profound mental retardation, moderate to severe dementia, or catastrophic neurological complications such as persistent vegetative state are unlikely candidates for ventilator support.’ Similar guidance has been issued in Washington and Arizona, with medics in the latter state instructed to ‘allocate resources to patients whose need is greater or whose prognosis is more likely to result in a positive outcome with limited resources.’ Disability advocacy groups have filed complaints against the US Department of Health and Human Servicesfor further clarication on the guidance. They are are seeking assurances that disabled people will not be discriminated against when it comes to receiving emergency care.  Those same groups say many of the million Americans who live with such disabilities are already at higher risk of Covid- because they often live in group homes – a known hotspot for deadly outbreaks of the virus. HHS spokesman Roger Severino has insisted that US civil rights laws ‘protect the equal dignity of every human being from ruthless utilitarianism,’ but experts have questioned whether those laws will still be applied during a nationwide medical crisis. Ari Ne’erman, a scholar at the Lurie Institiute for Disability Policy at Brandeis University in Waltham, Massachusetts, said: What we’re seeing here is a clash between disability rights law and ruthless utilitarian logic. What this is really about at the end of the day is whether our civil-rights laws still apply in a pandemic. I think that’s a pretty core question as to who we are as a country.  News website Tuscon also highlighted the tragic death of Emily Wallace, a  year-old woman with Downaposs syndrome who was infected with Covid- at her Georgia care home, and later died. Wallace previously hit the headlines after she and husband Richard became the first couple with Downaposs syndrome in Georgia to marry, with the pair living happily until Richard’s death in . She then moved into a care home, where she was infected by a care worker who had previously caught the virus.
